awd_titl_txt: AF:  Small:  An Algorithmic Approach to Collective Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal seeks to answer fundamental questions about collective behavior by attacking them from an "algorithmic" perspective.  The systems under consideration consist of agents communicating with one another and taking autonomous actions based on the information gathered along the way.  The agents could be members of a social network, flocking birds, flashing fireflies, swarming bacteria, etc. In all cases, agents are equipped with their own (possibly distinct) decision procedures that tell them what to do under what conditions and what agents to listen to. Out of this diversity of local interactions, striking patterns will often emerge: birds will form triangles; fireflies will reach perfect synchronization; bacteria will perform quorum sensing. How does one study emergent self-organization of this sort? The premise of this work is that an algorithmic approach to collective behavior holds the promise of a uniquely novel and powerful line of attack. 

The traditional tools for the study of complex systems draw mostly from the fields of dynamics and statistical physics. The PI's algorithmic approach will unfold in three phases. One is to develop general methods for decomposing complex systems into simpler ones. Just as graph clustering techniques are essential parts of the toolkit of network analysis, so "renormalization" methods are crucial for the analysis of self-organization and collective emergence. The second phase of this project entails the design of new tools for dynamic networks and time-varying random walks. The third phase is to investigate specific models of collective behavior, in particular classical systems for swarming and opinion dynamics. The challenge there is to classify the dynamic regimes of these systems (attractive, periodic, chaotic, Turing-universal, etc).

Broader impacts include curriculum development on this inter-disciplinary field and outreach presentations of the research at all levels.

por.por_cntn:
Complex social and biological systems lack the wealth of invariants found in physics. The attendant lack of symmetry makes their dynamics poorly suited to the tools of classical mathematics—electromagnetism has its equations but no one believes that cancer does. In this vein, the current surge of interest in “natural algorithms” echoes the growing recognition that algorithms, not differential equations, form the natural language of the living world. This belief rests on the fact that, unlike physics, biology is a historical science, where the concept of "memory" (taken in a broad sense) plays a key role: as it so happens, algorithms are the science of memory. The solar system is memoryless, in the sense that the positions and momenta of the planets today suffice to predict the the state of the system in a few years.  By contrast, it is still open what kind of (and how much) information is needed to specify the short-term dynamics of a living cell. Living systems are known to create memories at all timescales, generating sophisticated clocks and archival systems. To study these questions was the main goal of this project.

How do groups reach consensus without a leader? Under what conditions do they polarize into separate clusters? Most models of opinion dynamics treat agents as points in a metric space that move about under the influence of neighboring agents. This gives us an ideal platform to study network-based dynamics.To that effect, we built a number of analytical tools that offer novel lines of attack: for example, renormalization; s-energy; and algorithmic proofs.

The s-energy:  This is a new type of generating function associated with dynamic networks. Algorithmic proofs are protocols for distributed Lyapunov functions. Their investigation can be seen as an effort to build a bridge between the fields of dynamics and data structures.The s-energy has been found to play a key role in elucidating old questions about bird flocking.

Influence systems:  These systems consist of a finite set of agents that communicate among each other and evolve their states accordingly: their key feature is to adapt their topology of interaction as a function of their current states. As one of the most expressive models of multiagent dynamics, influence systems are the perfect vehicle for investigating the conflict between energy and entropy that drives the bifurcation analysis of many multiagent systems. Briefly, these seek to model open systems that absorb free energy into work while dissipating heat and producing entropy in the process. Using new techniques in network-based renormalization, we were able to explain the long time horizon behavior of large families of influence systems. The framework of influence systems has also proven an ideal platform to study the tradeoffs between robustness and evolvability in biology. 

Applications to opinion dynamics:  One of the main accomplishments of this project is a solution to the famous "2R-conjecture" in a mean-field model. Hegselmann- Krause systems have emerged as a model organism in the field of opinion dynamics. An HK system consists of a finite number of agents, each one represented by a point on a line. At any (discrete) time, each agent moves to the mass center of the agents within a prescribed distance R.  These systems were proposed to study how social groups cluster into polarized units or instead reach consensus. A well-known conjecture says that, if the agents are initially positioned at random, then they will end up in clusters that are roughly 2R apart. We proved this conjecture in a so-called mean-field model, where the number of agents is taken to infinity.
